speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Kent, Gloucester, and Edmund. [Kent and Gloucester converse. Edmund stands back.]

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I thought the King had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: It did always seem so to us; but now, in the division of the kingdom, it appears not which of the Dukes he values most, for equalities are so weigh'd that curiosity in neither can make choice of either's moiety.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Is not this your son, my lord?

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge. I have so often blush'd to acknowledge him that now I am braz'd to't.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I cannot conceive you.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Sir, this young fellow's mother could; whereupon she grew round-womb'd, and had indeed, sir, a son for her cradle ere she had a husband for her bed. Do you smell a fault?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year elder than this, who yet is no dearer in my account. Though this knave came something saucily into the world before he was sent for, yet was his mother fair, there was good sport at his making, and the whoreson must be acknowledged.- Do you know this noble gentleman, Edmund?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: No, my lord.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: My Lord of Kent. Remember him hereafter as my honourable friend.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: My services to your lordship.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I must love you, and sue to know you better.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Sir, I shall study deserving.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again. Sound a sennet. The King is coming.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter one bearing a coronet; then Lear; then the Dukes of Albany and Cornwall; next, Goneril, Regan, Cordelia, with Followers.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: I shall, my liege.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt [Gloucester and Edmund].

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Meantime we shall express our darker purpose. Give me the map there. Know we have divided In three our kingdom; and 'tis our fast intent To shake all cares and business from our age, Conferring them on younger strengths while we Unburthen'd crawl toward death. Our son of Cornwall, And you, our no less loving son of Albany, We have this hour a constant will to publish Our daughters' several dowers, that future strife May be prevented now. The princes, France and Burgundy, Great rivals in our youngest daughter's love, Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn, And here are to be answer'd. Tell me, my daughters (Since now we will divest us both of rule, Interest of territory, cares of state), Which of you shall we say doth love us most? That we our largest bounty may extend Where nature doth with merit challenge. Goneril, Our eldest-born, speak first.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Sir, I love you more than words can wield the matter; Dearer than eyesight, space, and liberty; Beyond what can be valued, rich or rare; No less than life, with grace, health, beauty, honour; As much as child e'er lov'd, or father found; A love that makes breath poor, and speech unable. Beyond all manner of so much I love you.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: [aside] What shall Cordelia speak? Love, and be silent.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Of all these bounds, even from this line to this, With shadowy forests and with champains rich'd, With plenteous rivers and wide-skirted meads, We make thee lady. To thine and Albany's issue Be this perpetual.- What says our second daughter, Our dearest Regan, wife to Cornwall? Speak.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Sir, I am made Of the selfsame metal that my sister is, And prize me at her worth. In my true heart I find she names my very deed of love; Only she comes too short, that I profess Myself an enemy to all other joys Which the most precious square of sense possesses, And find I am alone felicitate In your dear Highness' love.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: [aside] Then poor Cordelia! And yet not so; since I am sure my love's More richer than my tongue.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: To thee and thine hereditary ever Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom, No less in space, validity, and pleasure Than that conferr'd on Goneril.- Now, our joy, Although the last, not least; to whose young love The vines of France and milk of Burgundy Strive to be interest; what can you say to draw A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Nothing?

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Nothing.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Nothing can come of nothing. Speak again.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Unhappy that I am, I cannot heave My heart into my mouth. I love your Majesty According to my bond; no more nor less.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: How, how, Cordelia? Mend your speech a little, Lest it may mar your fortunes.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Good my lord, You have begot me, bred me, lov'd me; I Return those duties back as are right fit, Obey you, love you, and most honour you. Why have my sisters husbands, if they say They love you all? Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty. Sure I shall never marry like my sisters, To love my father all.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: But goes thy heart with this?

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Ay, good my lord.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: So young, and so untender?

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: So young, my lord, and true.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Let it be so! thy truth then be thy dower! For, by the sacred radiance of the sun, The mysteries of Hecate and the night; By all the operation of the orbs From whom we do exist and cease to be; Here I disclaim all my paternal care, Propinquity and property of blood, And as a stranger to my heart and me Hold thee from this for ever. The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbour'd, pitied, and reliev'd, As thou my sometime daughter.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Good my liege-

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Peace, Kent! Come not between the dragon and his wrath. I lov'd her most, and thought to set my rest On her kind nursery.- Hence and avoid my sight!- So be my grave my peace as here I give Her father's heart from her! Call France! Who stirs? Call Burgundy! Cornwall and Albany, With my two daughters' dowers digest this third; Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her. I do invest you jointly in my power, Preeminence, and all the large effects That troop with majesty. Ourself, by monthly course, With reservation of an hundred knights, By you to be sustain'd, shall our abode Make with you by due turns. Only we still retain The name, and all th' additions to a king. The sway, Revenue, execution of the rest, Beloved sons, be yours; which to confirm, This coronet part betwixt you.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honour'd as my king, Lov'd as my father, as my master follow'd, As my great patron thought on in my prayers-

speaker: Lear
turn_text: The bow is bent and drawn; make from the shaft.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Let it fall rather, though the fork invade The region of my heart! Be Kent unmannerly When Lear is mad. What wouldst thou do, old man? Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak When power to flattery bows? To plainness honour's bound When majesty falls to folly. Reverse thy doom; And in thy best consideration check This hideous rashness. Answer my life my judgment, Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least, Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound Reverbs no hollowness.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Kent, on thy life, no more!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: My life I never held but as a pawn To wage against thine enemies; nor fear to lose it, Thy safety being the motive.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Out of my sight!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: See better, Lear, and let me still remain The true blank of thine eye.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Now by Apollo-

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Now by Apollo, King, Thou swear'st thy gods in vain.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: O vassal! miscreant! [Lays his hand on his sword.]

speaker: Albany
turn_text: Dear sir, forbear!

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Dear sir, forbear!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Do! Kill thy physician, and the fee bestow Upon the foul disease. Revoke thy gift, Or, whilst I can vent clamour from my throat, I'll tell thee thou dost evil.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Hear me, recreant! On thine allegiance, hear me! Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow- Which we durst never yet- and with strain'd pride To come between our sentence and our power,- Which nor our nature nor our place can bear,- Our potency made good, take thy reward. Five days we do allot thee for provision To shield thee from diseases of the world, And on the sixth to turn thy hated back Upon our kingdom. If, on the tenth day following, Thy banish'd trunk be found in our dominions, The moment is thy death. Away! By Jupiter, This shall not be revok'd.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Fare thee well, King. Since thus thou wilt appear, Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here. [To Cordelia] The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid, That justly think'st and hast most rightly said! [To Regan and Goneril] And your large speeches may your deeds approve, That good effects may spring from words of love. Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu; He'll shape his old course in a country new.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Flourish. Enter Gloucester, with France and Burgundy; Attendants.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Here's France and Burgundy, my noble lord.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: My Lord of Burgundy, We first address toward you, who with this king Hath rivall'd for our daughter. What in the least Will you require in present dower with her, Or cease your quest of love?

speaker: Burgundy
turn_text: Most royal Majesty, I crave no more than hath your Highness offer'd, Nor will you tender less.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Right noble Burgundy, When she was dear to us, we did hold her so; But now her price is fall'n. Sir, there she stands. If aught within that little seeming substance, Or all of it, with our displeasure piec'd, And nothing more, may fitly like your Grace, She's there, and she is yours.

speaker: Burgundy
turn_text: I know no answer.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Will you, with those infirmities she owes, Unfriended, new adopted to our hate, Dow'r'd with our curse, and stranger'd with our oath, Take her, or leave her?

speaker: Burgundy
turn_text: Pardon me, royal sir. Election makes not up on such conditions.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Then leave her, sir; for, by the pow'r that made me, I tell you all her wealth. [To France] For you, great King, I would not from your love make such a stray To match you where I hate; therefore beseech you T' avert your liking a more worthier way Than on a wretch whom nature is asham'd Almost t' acknowledge hers.

speaker: France
turn_text: This is most strange, That she that even but now was your best object, The argument of your praise, balm of your age, Most best, most dearest, should in this trice of time Commit a thing so monstrous to dismantle So many folds of favour. Sure her offence Must be of such unnatural degree That monsters it, or your fore-vouch'd affection Fall'n into taint; which to believe of her Must be a faith that reason without miracle Should never plant in me.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: I yet beseech your Majesty, If for I want that glib and oily art To speak and purpose not, since what I well intend, I'll do't before I speak- that you make known It is no vicious blot, murther, or foulness, No unchaste action or dishonoured step, That hath depriv'd me of your grace and favour; But even for want of that for which I am richer- A still-soliciting eye, and such a tongue As I am glad I have not, though not to have it Hath lost me in your liking.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Better thou Hadst not been born than not t' have pleas'd me better.

speaker: France
turn_text: Is it but this- a tardiness in nature Which often leaves the history unspoke That it intends to do? My Lord of Burgundy, What say you to the lady? Love's not love When it is mingled with regards that stands Aloof from th' entire point. Will you have her? She is herself a dowry.

speaker: Burgundy
turn_text: Royal Lear, Give but that portion which yourself propos'd, And here I take Cordelia by the hand, Duchess of Burgundy.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Nothing! I have sworn; I am firm.

speaker: Burgundy
turn_text: I am sorry then you have so lost a father That you must lose a husband.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Peace be with Burgundy! Since that respects of fortune are his love, I shall not be his wife.

speaker: France
turn_text: Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being poor; Most choice, forsaken; and most lov'd, despis'd! Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon. Be it lawful I take up what's cast away. Gods, gods! 'tis strange that from their cold'st neglect My love should kindle to inflam'd respect. Thy dow'rless daughter, King, thrown to my chance, Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France. Not all the dukes in wat'rish Burgundy Can buy this unpriz'd precious maid of me. Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind. Thou losest here, a better where to find.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Thou hast her, France; let her be thine; for we Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see That face of hers again. Therefore be gone Without our grace, our love, our benison. Come, noble Burgundy.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Flourish. Exeunt Lear, Burgundy, [Cornwall, Albany, Gloucester, and Attendants].

speaker: France
turn_text: Bid farewell to your sisters.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: The jewels of our father, with wash'd eyes Cordelia leaves you. I know you what you are; And, like a sister, am most loath to call Your faults as they are nam'd. Use well our father. To your professed bosoms I commit him; But yet, alas, stood I within his grace, I would prefer him to a better place! So farewell to you both.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Prescribe not us our duties.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Let your study Be to content your lord, who hath receiv'd you At fortune's alms. You have obedience scanted, And well are worth the want that you have wanted.

speaker: Cordelia
turn_text: Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides. Who cover faults, at last shame them derides. Well may you prosper!

speaker: France
turn_text: Come, my fair Cordelia.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt France and Cordelia.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Sister, it is not little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both. I think our father will hence to-night.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: That's most certain, and with you; next month with us.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: You see how full of changes his age is. The observation we have made of it hath not been little. He always lov'd our sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: 'Tis the infirmity of his age; yet he hath ever but slenderly known himself.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash; then must we look to receive from his age, not alone the imperfections of long-ingraffed condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent's banishment.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and him. Pray you let's hit together. If our father carry authority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender of his will but offend us.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: We shall further think on't.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: We must do something, and i' th' heat.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter [Edmund the] Bastard solus, [with a letter].

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Thou, Nature, art my goddess; to thy law My services are bound. Wherefore should I Stand in the plague of custom, and permit The curiosity of nations to deprive me, For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines Lag of a brother? Why bastard? wherefore base? When my dimensions are as well compact, My mind as generous, and my shape as true, As honest madam's issue? Why brand they us With base? with baseness? bastardy? base, base? Who, in the lusty stealth of nature, take More composition and fierce quality Than doth, within a dull, stale, tired bed, Go to th' creating a whole tribe of fops Got 'tween asleep and wake? Well then, Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land. Our father's love is to the bastard Edmund As to th' legitimate. Fine word- 'legitimate'! Well, my legitimate, if this letter speed, And my invention thrive, Edmund the base Shall top th' legitimate. I grow; I prosper. Now, gods, stand up for bastards!

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Gloucester.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Kent banish'd thus? and France in choler parted? And the King gone to-night? subscrib'd his pow'r? Confin'd to exhibition? All this done Upon the gad? Edmund, how now? What news?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: So please your lordship, none. [Puts up the letter.]

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I know no news, my lord.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: What paper were you reading?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: No? What needed then that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket? The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself. Let's see. Come, if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I beseech you, sir, pardon me. It is a letter from my brother that I have not all o'er-read; and for so much as I have perus'd, I find it not fit for your o'erlooking.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Give me the letter, sir.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I shall offend, either to detain or give it. The contents, as in part I understand them, are to blame.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Let's see, let's see!

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I hope, for my brother's justification, he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: (reads) 'This policy and reverence of age makes the world bitter to the best of our times; keeps our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish them. I begin to find an idle and fond bondage in the oppression of aged tyranny, who sways, not as it hath power, but as it is suffer'd. Come to me, that of this I may speak more. If our father would sleep till I wak'd him, you should enjoy half his revenue for ever, and live the beloved of your brother, 'EDGAR.' Hum! Conspiracy? 'Sleep till I wak'd him, you should enjoy half his revenue.' My son Edgar! Had he a hand to write this? a heart and brain to breed it in? When came this to you? Who brought it?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: It was not brought me, my lord: there's the cunning of it. I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: You know the character to be your brother's?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his; but in respect of that, I would fain think it were not.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: It is his.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: It is his hand, my lord; but I hope his heart is not in the contents.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Hath he never before sounded you in this business?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Never, my lord. But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit that, sons at perfect age, and fathers declining, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: O villain, villain! His very opinion in the letter! Abhorred villain! Unnatural, detested, brutish villain! worse than brutish! Go, sirrah, seek him. I'll apprehend him. Abominable villain! Where is he?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I do not well know, my lord. If it shall please you to suspend your indignation against my brother till you can derive from him better testimony of his intent, you should run a certain course; where, if you violently proceed against him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great gap in your own honour and shake in pieces the heart of his obedience. I dare pawn down my life for him that he hath writ this to feel my affection to your honour, and to no other pretence of danger.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Think you so?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: If your honour judge it meet, I will place you where you shall hear us confer of this and by an auricular assurance have your satisfaction, and that without any further delay than this very evening.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: He cannot be such a monster.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Nor is not, sure.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him. Heaven and earth! Edmund, seek him out; wind me into him, I pray you; frame the business after your own wisdom. I would unstate myself to be in a due resolution.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I will seek him, sir, presently; convey the business as I shall find means, and acquaint you withal.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us. Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself scourg'd by the sequent effects. Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide. In cities, mutinies; in countries, discord; in palaces, treason; and the bond crack'd 'twixt son and father. This villain of mine comes under the prediction; there's son against father: the King falls from bias of nature; there's father against child. We have seen the best of our time. Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves. Find out this villain, Edmund; it shall lose thee nothing; do it carefully. And the noble and true-hearted Kent banish'd! his offence, honesty! 'Tis strange.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: This is the excellent foppery of the world, that, when we are sick in fortune, often the surfeit of our own behaviour, we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars; as if we were villains on necessity; fools by heavenly compulsion; knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical pre-dominance; drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforc'd obedience of planetary influence; and all that we are evil in, by a divine thrusting on. An admirable evasion of whore-master man, to lay his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! My father compounded with my mother under the Dragon's Tail, and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous. Fut! I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing. Edgar-

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Edgar.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: and pat! he comes, like the catastrophe of the old comedy. My cue is villainous melancholy, with a sigh like Tom o' Bedlam. O, these eclipses do portend these divisions! Fa, sol, la, mi.

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: How now, brother Edmund? What serious contemplation are you in?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I am thinking, brother, of a prediction I read this other day, what should follow these eclipses.

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: Do you busy yourself with that?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I promise you, the effects he writes of succeed unhappily: as of unnaturalness between the child and the parent; death, dearth, dissolutions of ancient amities; divisions in state, menaces and maledictions against king and nobles; needless diffidences, banishment of friends, dissipation of cohorts, nuptial breaches, and I know not what.

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: How long have you been a sectary astronomical?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Come, come! When saw you my father last?

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: The night gone by.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Spake you with him?

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: Ay, two hours together.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Parted you in good terms? Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance?

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: None at all.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended him; and at my entreaty forbear his presence until some little time hath qualified the heat of his displeasure, which at this instant so rageth in him that with the mischief of your person it would scarcely allay.

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: Some villain hath done me wrong.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: That's my fear. I pray you have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower; and, as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak. Pray ye, go! There's my key. If you do stir abroad, go arm'd.

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: Arm'd, brother?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Brother, I advise you to the best. Go arm'd. I am no honest man if there be any good meaning toward you. I have told you what I have seen and heard; but faintly, nothing like the image and horror of it. Pray you, away!

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: Shall I hear from you anon?

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I do serve you in this business.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit Edgar.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: A credulous father! and a brother noble, Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none; on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy! I see the business. Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit; All with me's meet that I can fashion fit.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Goneril and [her] Steward [Oswald].

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Did my father strike my gentleman for chiding of his fool?

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Ay, madam.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: By day and night, he wrongs me! Every hour He flashes into one gross crime or other That sets us all at odds. I'll not endure it. His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us On every trifle. When he returns from hunting, I will not speak with him. Say I am sick. If you come slack of former services, You shall do well; the fault of it I'll answer.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: [Horns within.]

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: He's coming, madam; I hear him.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Put on what weary negligence you please, You and your fellows. I'd have it come to question. If he distaste it, let him to our sister, Whose mind and mine I know in that are one, Not to be overrul'd. Idle old man, That still would manage those authorities That he hath given away! Now, by my life, Old fools are babes again, and must be us'd With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abus'd. Remember what I have said.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Very well, madam.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: And let his knights have colder looks among you. What grows of it, no matter. Advise your fellows so. I would breed from hence occasions, and I shall, That I may speak. I'll write straight to my sister To hold my very course. Prepare for dinner.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Kent, [disguised].

speaker: Kent
turn_text: If but as well I other accents borrow, That can my speech defuse, my good intent May carry through itself to that full issue For which I raz'd my likeness. Now, banish'd Kent, If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemn'd, So may it come, thy master, whom thou lov'st, Shall find thee full of labours.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Horns within. Enter Lear, [Knights,] and Attendants.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Let me not stay a jot for dinner; go get it ready. [Exit an Attendant.] How now? What art thou?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: A man, sir.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What dost thou profess? What wouldst thou with us?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I do profess to be no less than I seem, to serve him truly that will put me in trust, to love him that is honest, to converse with him that is wise and says little, to fear judgment, to fight when I cannot choose, and to eat no fish.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What art thou?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the King.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: If thou be'st as poor for a subject as he's for a king, thou art poor enough. What wouldst thou?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Service.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Who wouldst thou serve?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: You.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Dost thou know me, fellow?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: No, sir; but you have that in your countenance which I would fain call master.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What's that?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Authority.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What services canst thou do?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in telling it and deliver a plain message bluntly. That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in, and the best of me is diligence.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: How old art thou?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything. I have years on my back forty-eight.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Follow me; thou shalt serve me. If I like thee no worse after dinner, I will not part from thee yet. Dinner, ho, dinner! Where's my knave? my fool? Go you and call my fool hither.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: [Exit an attendant.]

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter [Oswald the] Steward.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: You, you, sirrah, where's my daughter?

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: So please you- Exit.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What says the fellow there? Call the clotpoll back. [Exit a Knight.] Where's my fool, ho? I think the world's asleep.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: [Enter Knight]

speaker: Lear
turn_text: How now? Where's that mongrel?

speaker: Knight
turn_text: He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Why came not the slave back to me when I call'd him?

speaker: Knight
turn_text: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner, he would not.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: He would not?

speaker: Knight
turn_text: My lord, I know not what the matter is; but to my judgment your Highness is not entertain'd with that ceremonious affection as you were wont. There's a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the Duke himself also and your daughter.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Ha! say'st thou so?

speaker: Knight
turn_text: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken; for my duty cannot be silent when I think your Highness wrong'd.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Thou but rememb'rest me of mine own conception. I have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretence and purpose of unkindness. I will look further into't. But where's my fool? I have not seen him this two days.

speaker: Knight
turn_text: Since my young lady's going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: No more of that; I have noted it well. Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her. [Exit Knight.] Go you, call hither my fool.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: [Exit an Attendant.]

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter [Oswald the] Steward.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: O, you, sir, you! Come you hither, sir. Who am I, sir?

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: My lady's father.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: 'My lady's father'? My lord's knave! You whoreson dog! you slave! you cur!

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: I am none of these, my lord; I beseech your pardon.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal? [Strikes him.]

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: I'll not be strucken, my lord.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Nor tripp'd neither, you base football player? [Trips up his heels.]

speaker: Lear
turn_text: I thank thee, fellow. Thou serv'st me, and I'll love thee.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Come, sir, arise, away! I'll teach you differences. Away, away! If you will measure your lubber's length again, tarry; but away! Go to! Have you wisdom? So. [Pushes him out.]

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee. There's earnest of thy service. [Gives money.]

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Fool.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Let me hire him too. Here's my coxcomb. [Offers Kent his cap.]

speaker: Lear
turn_text: How now, my pretty knave? How dost thou?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Sirrah, you were best take my coxcomb.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Why, fool?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Why? For taking one's part that's out of favour. Nay, an thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch cold shortly. There, take my coxcomb! Why, this fellow hath banish'd two on's daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will. If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.- How now, nuncle? Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters!

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Why, my boy?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: If I gave them all my living, I'ld keep my coxcombs myself. There's mine! beg another of thy daughters.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Take heed, sirrah- the whip.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Truth's a dog must to kennel; he must be whipp'd out, when Lady the brach may stand by th' fire and stink.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: A pestilent gall to me!

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Sirrah, I'll teach thee a speech.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Do.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Mark it, nuncle. Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest; Leave thy drink and thy whore, And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than two tens to a score.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: This is nothing, fool.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Then 'tis like the breath of an unfeed lawyer- you gave me nothing for't. Can you make no use of nothing, nuncle?

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Why, no, boy. Nothing can be made out of nothing.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: [to Kent] Prithee tell him, so much the rent of his land comes to. He will not believe a fool.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: A bitter fool!

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet fool?

speaker: Lear
turn_text: No, lad; teach me.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: That lord that counsell'd thee To give away thy land, Come place him here by me- Do thou for him stand. The sweet and bitter fool Will presently appear; The one in motley here, The other found out there.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Dost thou call me fool, boy?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: All thy other titles thou hast given away; that thou wast born with.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: This is not altogether fool, my lord.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: No, faith; lords and great men will not let me. If I had a monopoly out, they would have part on't. And ladies too, they will not let me have all the fool to myself; they'll be snatching. Give me an egg, nuncle, and I'll give thee two crowns.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What two crowns shall they be?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Why, after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat up the meat, the two crowns of the egg. When thou clovest thy crown i' th' middle and gav'st away both parts, thou bor'st thine ass on thy back o'er the dirt. Thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown when thou gav'st thy golden one away. If I speak like myself in this, let him be whipp'd that first finds it so. [Sings] Fools had ne'er less grace in a year, For wise men are grown foppish; They know not how their wits to wear, Their manners are so apish.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: I have us'd it, nuncle, ever since thou mad'st thy daughters thy mother; for when thou gav'st them the rod, and put'st down thine own breeches, [Sings] Then they for sudden joy did weep, And I for sorrow sung, That such a king should play bo-peep And go the fools among. Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to lie. I would fain learn to lie.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: An you lie, sirrah, we'll have you whipp'd.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are. They'll have me whipp'd for speaking true; thou'lt have me whipp'd for lying; and sometimes I am whipp'd for holding my peace. I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool! And yet I would not be thee, nuncle. Thou hast pared thy wit o' both sides and left nothing i' th' middle. Here comes one o' the parings.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Goneril.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: How now, daughter? What makes that frontlet on? Methinks you are too much o' late i' th' frown.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for her frowning. Now thou art an O without a figure. I am better than thou art now: I am a fool, thou art nothing. [To Goneril] Yes, forsooth, I will hold my tongue. So your face bids me, though you say nothing. Mum, mum! He that keeps nor crust nor crum, Weary of all, shall want some.- [Points at Lear] That's a sheal'd peascod.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Not only, sir, this your all-licens'd fool, But other of your insolent retinue Do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking forth In rank and not-to-be-endured riots. Sir, I had thought, by making this well known unto you, To have found a safe redress, but now grow fearful, By what yourself, too, late have spoke and done, That you protect this course, and put it on By your allowance; which if you should, the fault Would not scape censure, nor the redresses sleep, Which, in the tender of a wholesome weal, Might in their working do you that offence Which else were shame, that then necessity Must call discreet proceeding.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: For you know, nuncle, The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long That it had it head bit off by it young. So out went the candle, and we were left darkling.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Are you our daughter?

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Come, sir, I would you would make use of that good wisdom Whereof I know you are fraught, and put away These dispositions that of late transform you From what you rightly are.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse? Whoop, Jug, I love thee!

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Doth any here know me? This is not Lear. Doth Lear walk thus? speak thus? Where are his eyes? Either his notion weakens, his discernings Are lethargied- Ha! waking? 'Tis not so! Who is it that can tell me who I am?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Lear's shadow.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: I would learn that; for, by the marks of sovereignty, Knowledge, and reason, I should be false persuaded I had daughters.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Which they will make an obedient father.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Your name, fair gentlewoman?

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savour Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you To understand my purposes aright. As you are old and reverend, you should be wise. Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires; Men so disorder'd, so debosh'd, and bold That this our court, infected with their manners, Shows like a riotous inn. Epicurism and lust Make it more like a tavern or a brothel Than a grac'd palace. The shame itself doth speak For instant remedy. Be then desir'd By her that else will take the thing she begs A little to disquantity your train, And the remainder that shall still depend To be such men as may besort your age, Which know themselves, and you.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Darkness and devils! Saddle my horses! Call my train together! Degenerate bastard, I'll not trouble thee; Yet have I left a daughter.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: You strike my people, and your disorder'd rabble Make servants of their betters.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Albany.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Woe that too late repents!- O, sir, are you come? Is it your will? Speak, sir!- Prepare my horses. Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend, More hideous when thou show'st thee in a child Than the sea-monster!

speaker: Albany
turn_text: Pray, sir, be patient.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: [to Goneril] Detested kite, thou liest! My train are men of choice and rarest parts, That all particulars of duty know And in the most exact regard support The worships of their name.- O most small fault, How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show! Which, like an engine, wrench'd my frame of nature From the fix'd place; drew from my heart all love And added to the gall. O Lear, Lear, Lear! Beat at this gate that let thy folly in [Strikes his head.] And thy dear judgment out! Go, go, my people.

speaker: Albany
turn_text: My lord, I am guiltless, as I am ignorant Of what hath mov'd you.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: It may be so, my lord. Hear, Nature, hear! dear goddess, hear! Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend To make this creature fruitful. Into her womb convey sterility; Dry up in her the organs of increase; And from her derogate body never spring A babe to honour her! If she must teem, Create her child of spleen, that it may live And be a thwart disnatur'd torment to her. Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth, With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks, Turn all her mother's pains and benefits To laughter and contempt, that she may feel How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is To have a thankless child! Away, away! Exit.

speaker: Albany
turn_text: Now, gods that we adore, whereof comes this?

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Never afflict yourself to know the cause; But let his disposition have that scope That dotage gives it.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Lear.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What, fifty of my followers at a clap? Within a fortnight?

speaker: Albany
turn_text: What's the matter, sir?

speaker: Lear
turn_text: I'll tell thee. [To Goneril] Life and death! I am asham'd That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus; That these hot tears, which break from me perforce, Should make thee worth them. Blasts and fogs upon thee! Th' untented woundings of a father's curse Pierce every sense about thee!- Old fond eyes, Beweep this cause again, I'll pluck ye out, And cast you, with the waters that you lose, To temper clay. Yea, is it come to this? Let it be so. Yet have I left a daughter, Who I am sure is kind and comfortable. When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails She'll flay thy wolvish visage. Thou shalt find That I'll resume the shape which thou dost think I have cast off for ever; thou shalt, I warrant thee.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt [Lear, Kent, and Attendants].

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Do you mark that, my lord?

speaker: Albany
turn_text: I cannot be so partial, Goneril, To the great love I bear you -

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Pray you, content.- What, Oswald, ho! [To the Fool] You, sir, more knave than fool, after your master!

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Nuncle Lear, nuncle Lear, tarry! Take the fool with thee. A fox when one has caught her, And such a daughter, Should sure to the slaughter, If my cap would buy a halter. So the fool follows after. Exit.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: This man hath had good counsel! A hundred knights? 'Tis politic and safe to let him keep At point a hundred knights; yes, that on every dream, Each buzz, each fancy, each complaint, dislike, He may enguard his dotage with their pow'rs And hold our lives in mercy.- Oswald, I say!

speaker: Albany
turn_text: Well, you may fear too far.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Safer than trust too far. Let me still take away the harms I fear, Not fear still to be taken. I know his heart. What he hath utter'd I have writ my sister. If she sustain him and his hundred knights, When I have show'd th' unfitness-

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter [Oswald the] Steward.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: How now, Oswald? What, have you writ that letter to my sister?

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Yes, madam.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Take you some company, and away to horse! Inform her full of my particular fear, And thereto add such reasons of your own As may compact it more. Get you gone, And hasten your return. [Exit Oswald.] No, no, my lord! This milky gentleness and course of yours, Though I condemn it not, yet, under pardon, You are much more at task for want of wisdom Than prais'd for harmful mildness.

speaker: Albany
turn_text: How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell. Striving to better, oft we mar what's well.

speaker: Goneril
turn_text: Nay then-

speaker: Albany
turn_text: Well, well; th' event.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Lear, Kent, and Fool.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: Go you before to Gloucester with these letters. Acquaint my daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her demand out of the letter. If your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there afore you.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Kent
turn_text: I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: If a man's brains were in's heels, were't not in danger of kibes?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: Ay, boy.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Then I prithee be merry. Thy wit shall ne'er go slip-shod.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: Ha, ha, ha!

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly; for though she's as like this as a crab's like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: What canst tell, boy?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: She'll taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. Thou canst tell why one's nose stands i' th' middle on's face?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: No.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Why, to keep one's eyes of either side's nose, that what a man cannot smell out, 'a may spy into.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: I did her wrong.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: No.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Nor I neither; but I can tell why a snail has a house.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: Why?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Why, to put's head in; not to give it away to his daughters, and leave his horns without a case.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: I will forget my nature. So kind a father!- Be my horses ready?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Thy asses are gone about 'em. The reason why the seven stars are no moe than seven is a pretty reason.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: Because they are not eight?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Yes indeed. Thou wouldst make a good fool.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: To tak't again perforce! Monster ingratitude!

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I'ld have thee beaten for being old before thy time.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: How's that?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven! Keep me in temper; I would not be mad!

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: [Enter a Gentleman.]

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: How now? Are the horses ready?

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Gentleman
turn_text: Ready, my lord.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Lear
turn_text: Come, boy.

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: Fool
turn_text: She that's a maid now, and laughs at my departure, Shall not be a maid long, unless things be cut shorter

location: Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter [Edmund the] Bastard and Curan, meeting.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Save thee, Curan.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Curan
turn_text: And you, sir. I have been with your father, and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his Duchess will be here with him this night.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: How comes that?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Curan
turn_text: Nay, I know not. You have heard of the news abroad- I mean the whisper'd ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Not I. Pray you, what are they?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Curan
turn_text: Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Not a word.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Curan
turn_text: You may do, then, in time. Fare you well, sir.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: The Duke be here to-night? The better! best! This weaves itself perforce into my business. My father hath set guard to take my brother; And I have one thing, of a queasy question, Which I must act. Briefness and fortune, work! Brother, a word! Descend! Brother, I say!

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Edgar.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: My father watches. O sir, fly this place! Intelligence is given where you are hid. You have now the good advantage of the night. Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall? He's coming hither; now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him. Have you nothing said Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany? Advise yourself.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edgar
turn_text: I am sure on't, not a word.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I hear my father coming. Pardon me! In cunning I must draw my sword upon you. Draw, seem to defend yourself; now quit you well.- Yield! Come before my father. Light, ho, here! Fly, brother.- Torches, torches!- So farewell.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit Edgar.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion Of my more fierce endeavour. [Stabs his arm.] I have seen drunkards Do more than this in sport.- Father, father!- Stop, stop! No help?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Gloucester, and Servants with torches.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Now, Edmund, where's the villain?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out, Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the moon To stand 's auspicious mistress.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: But where is he?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Look, sir, I bleed.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Where is the villain, Edmund?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Fled this way, sir. When by no means he could-

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Pursue him, ho! Go after. [Exeunt some Servants]. By no means what?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Persuade me to the murther of your lordship; But that I told him the revenging gods 'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend; Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond The child was bound to th' father- sir, in fine, Seeing how loathly opposite I stood To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion With his prepared sword he charges home My unprovided body, lanch'd mine arm; But when he saw my best alarum'd spirits, Bold in the quarrel's right, rous'd to th' encounter, Or whether gasted by the noise I made, Full suddenly he fled.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Let him fly far. Not in this land shall he remain uncaught; And found- dispatch. The noble Duke my master, My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night. By his authority I will proclaim it That he which find, him shall deserve our thanks, Bringing the murderous caitiff to the stake; He that conceals him, death.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: When I dissuaded him from his intent And found him pight to do it, with curst speech I threaten'd to discover him. He replied, 'Thou unpossessing bastard, dost thou think, If I would stand against thee, would the reposal Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee Make thy words faith'd? No. What I should deny (As this I would; ay, though thou didst produce My very character), I'ld turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice; And thou must make a dullard of the world, If they not thought the profits of my death Were very pregnant and potential spurs To make thee seek it.'

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Strong and fast'ned villain! Would he deny his letter? I never got him.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Tucket within.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Hark, the Duke's trumpets! I know not why he comes. All ports I'll bar; the villain shall not scape; The Duke must grant me that. Besides, his picture I will send far and near, that all the kingdom May have due note of him, and of my land, Loyal and natural boy, I'll work the means To make thee capable.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Cornwall, Regan, and Attendants.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: How now, my noble friend? Since I came hither (Which I can call but now) I have heard strange news.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Regan
turn_text: If it be true, all vengeance comes too short Which can pursue th' offender. How dost, my lord?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: O madam, my old heart is crack'd, it's crack'd!

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Regan
turn_text: What, did my father's godson seek your life? He whom my father nam'd? Your Edgar?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: O lady, lady, shame would have it hid!

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Regan
turn_text: Was he not companion with the riotous knights That tend upon my father?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: I know not, madam. 'Tis too bad, too bad!

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: Yes, madam, he was of that consort.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Regan
turn_text: No marvel then though he were ill affected. 'Tis they have put him on the old man's death, To have th' expense and waste of his revenues. I have this present evening from my sister Been well inform'd of them, and with such cautions That, if they come to sojourn at my house, I'll not be there.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Nor I, assure thee, Regan. Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father A childlike office.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: 'Twas my duty, sir.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: He did bewray his practice, and receiv'd This hurt you see, striving to apprehend him.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Is he pursued?

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Ay, my good lord.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: If he be taken, he shall never more Be fear'd of doing harm. Make your own purpose, How in my strength you please. For you, Edmund, Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant So much commend itself, you shall be ours. Natures of such deep trust we shall much need; You we first seize on.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Edmund
turn_text: I shall serve you, sir, Truly, however else.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: For him I thank your Grace.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: You know not why we came to visit you-

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Regan
turn_text: Thus out of season, threading dark-ey'd night. Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise, Wherein we must have use of your advice. Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister, Of differences, which I best thought it fit To answer from our home. The several messengers From hence attend dispatch. Our good old friend, Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow Your needful counsel to our business, Which craves the instant use.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: I serve you, madam. Your Graces are right welcome.

location: A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester
speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt. Flourish.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Kent and [Oswald the] Steward, severally.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Good dawning to thee, friend. Art of this house?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Ay.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Where may we set our horses?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I' th' mire.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Prithee, if thou lov'st me, tell me.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I love thee not.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Why then, I care not for thee.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make thee care for me.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Fellow, I know thee.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: What dost thou know me for?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave; a lily-liver'd, action-taking, whoreson, glass-gazing, superserviceable, finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch; one whom I will beat into clamorous whining, if thou deny the least syllable of thy addition.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that's neither known of thee nor knows thee!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: What a brazen-fac'd varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me! Is it two days ago since I beat thee and tripp'd up thy heels before the King? [Draws his sword.] Draw, you rogue! for, though it be night, yet the moon shines. I'll make a sop o' th' moonshine o' you. Draw, you whoreson cullionly barbermonger! draw!

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Away! I have nothing to do with thee.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Draw, you rascal! You come with letters against the King, and take Vanity the puppet's part against the royalty of her father. Draw, you rogue, or I'll so carbonado your shanks! Draw, you rascal! Come your ways!

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Help, ho! murther! help!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Strike, you slave! Stand, rogue! Stand, you neat slave! Strike! [Beats him.]

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: Help, ho! murther! murther!

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Edmund, with his rapier drawn, Gloucester, Cornwall, Regan, Servants.

speaker: Edmund
turn_text: How now? What's the matter? [Parts them.]

speaker: Kent
turn_text: With you, goodman boy, an you please! Come, I'll flesh ye! Come on, young master!

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Weapons? arms? What's the matter here?

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Keep peace, upon your lives! He dies that strikes again. What is the matter?

speaker: Regan
turn_text: The messengers from our sister and the King.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: What is your difference? Speak.

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: I am scarce in breath, my lord.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: No marvel, you have so bestirr'd your valour. You cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee; a tailor made thee.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Thou art a strange fellow. A tailor make a man?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Ay, a tailor, sir. A stonecutter or a painter could not have made him so ill, though he had been but two hours at the trade.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Speak yet, how grew your quarrel?

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spar'd At suit of his grey beard-

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Thou whoreson zed! thou unnecessary letter! My lord, if you'll give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar and daub the walls of a jakes with him. 'Spare my grey beard,' you wagtail?

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Peace, sirrah! You beastly knave, know you no reverence?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Why art thou angry?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: That such a slave as this should wear a sword, Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these, Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion That in the natures of their lords rebel, Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder moods; Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks With every gale and vary of their masters, Knowing naught (like dogs) but following. A plague upon your epileptic visage! Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool? Goose, an I had you upon Sarum Plain, I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: What, art thou mad, old fellow?

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: How fell you out? Say that.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: No contraries hold more antipathy Than I and such a knave.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Why dost thou call him knave? What is his fault?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: His countenance likes me not.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: No more perchance does mine, or his, or hers.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain. I have seen better faces in my time Than stands on any shoulder that I see Before me at this instant.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: This is some fellow Who, having been prais'd for bluntness, doth affect A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb Quite from his nature. He cannot flatter, he! An honest mind and plain- he must speak truth! An they will take it, so; if not, he's plain. These kind of knaves I know which in this plainness Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends Than twenty silly-ducking observants That stretch their duties nicely.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Sir, in good faith, in sincere verity, Under th' allowance of your great aspect, Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire On flickering Phoebus' front-

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: What mean'st by this?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no flatterer. He that beguil'd you in a plain accent was a plain knave, which, for my part, I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to't.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: What was th' offence you gave him?

speaker: Oswald
turn_text: I never gave him any. It pleas'd the King his master very late To strike at me, upon his misconstruction; When he, conjunct, and flattering his displeasure, Tripp'd me behind; being down, insulted, rail'd And put upon him such a deal of man That worthied him, got praises of the King For him attempting who was self-subdu'd; And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit, Drew on me here again.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Fetch forth the stocks! You stubborn ancient knave, you reverent braggart, We'll teach you-

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Sir, I am too old to learn. Call not your stocks for me. I serve the King; On whose employment I was sent to you. You shall do small respect, show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master, Stocking his messenger.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Fetch forth the stocks! As I have life and honour, There shall he sit till noon.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Till noon? Till night, my lord, and all night too!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Why, madam, if I were your father's dog, You should not use me so.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Sir, being his knave, I will.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: This is a fellow of the selfsame colour Our sister speaks of. Come, bring away the stocks!

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Stocks brought out.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Let me beseech your Grace not to do so. His fault is much, and the good King his master Will check him for't. Your purpos'd low correction Is such as basest and contemn'dest wretches For pilf'rings and most common trespasses Are punish'd with. The King must take it ill That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrain'd.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: I'll answer that.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: My sister may receive it much more worse, To have her gentleman abus'd, assaulted, For following her affairs. Put in his legs. [Kent is put in the stocks.] Come, my good lord, away.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exeunt [all but Gloucester and Kent].

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: I am sorry for thee, friend. 'Tis the Duke's pleasure, Whose disposition, all the world well knows, Will not be rubb'd nor stopp'd. I'll entreat for thee.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Pray do not, sir. I have watch'd and travell'd hard. Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I'll whistle. A good man's fortune may grow out at heels. Give you good morrow!

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: The Duke 's to blame in this; 'twill be ill taken.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Good King, that must approve the common saw, Thou out of heaven's benediction com'st To the warm sun! Approach, thou beacon to this under globe, That by thy comfortable beams I may Peruse this letter. Nothing almost sees miracles But misery. I know 'tis from Cordelia, Who hath most fortunately been inform'd Of my obscured course- and [reads] 'shall find time From this enormous state, seeking to give Losses their remedies'- All weary and o'erwatch'd, Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold This shameful lodging. Fortune, good night; smile once more, turn thy wheel.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Sleeps.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Edgar.

speaker: Edgar
turn_text: I heard myself proclaim'd, And by the happy hollow of a tree Escap'd the hunt. No port is free, no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking. Whiles I may scape, I will preserve myself; and am bethought To take the basest and most poorest shape That ever penury, in contempt of man, Brought near to beast. My face I'll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky. The country gives me proof and precedent Of Bedlam beggars, who, with roaring voices, Strike in their numb'd and mortified bare arms Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary; And with this horrible object, from low farms, Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes, and mills, Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers, Enforce their charity. 'Poor Turlygod! poor Tom!' That's something yet! Edgar I nothing am.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Kent in the stocks; Enter Lear, Fool, and Gentleman.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: 'Tis strange that they should so depart from home, And not send back my messenger.

speaker: Gentleman
turn_text: As I learn'd, The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Hail to thee, noble master!

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Ha! Mak'st thou this shame thy pastime?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: No, my lord.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Ha, ha! look! he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the head, dogs and bears by th' neck, monkeys by th' loins, and men by th' legs. When a man's over-lusty at legs, then he wears wooden nether-stocks.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: What's he that hath so much thy place mistook To set thee here?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: It is both he and she- Your son and daughter.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: No.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Yes.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: No, I say.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: I say yea.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: No, no, they would not!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Yes, they have.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: By Jupiter, I swear no!

speaker: Kent
turn_text: By Juno, I swear ay!

speaker: Lear
turn_text: They durst not do't; They would not, could not do't. 'Tis worse than murther To do upon respect such violent outrage. Resolve me with all modest haste which way Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage, Coming from us.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: My lord, when at their home I did commend your Highness' letters to them, Ere I was risen from the place that show'd My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post, Stew'd in his haste, half breathless, panting forth From Goneril his mistress salutations; Deliver'd letters, spite of intermission, Which presently they read; on whose contents, They summon'd up their meiny, straight took horse, Commanded me to follow and attend The leisure of their answer, gave me cold looks, And meeting here the other messenger, Whose welcome I perceiv'd had poison'd mine- Being the very fellow which of late Display'd so saucily against your Highness- Having more man than wit about me, drew. He rais'd the house with loud and coward cries. Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers.

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Winter's not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way. Fathers that wear rags Do make their children blind; But fathers that bear bags Shall see their children kind. Fortune, that arrant whore, Ne'er turns the key to th' poor. But for all this, thou shalt have as many dolours for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: O, how this mother swells up toward my heart! Hysterica passio! Down, thou climbing sorrow! Thy element's below! Where is this daughter?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: With the Earl, sir, here within.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Follow me not; Stay here.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: Gentleman
turn_text: Made you no more offence but what you speak of?

speaker: Kent
turn_text: None. How chance the King comes with so small a number?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou'dst well deserv'd it.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Why, fool?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: We'll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee there's no labouring i' th' winter. All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him that's stinking. Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with following it; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw thee after. When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again. I would have none but knaves follow it, since a fool gives it. That sir which serves and seeks for gain, And follows but for form, Will pack when it begins to rain And leave thee in the storm. But I will tarry; the fool will stay, And let the wise man fly. The knave turns fool that runs away; The fool no knave, perdy.

speaker: Kent
turn_text: Where learn'd you this, fool?

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Not i' th' stocks, fool.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Lear and Gloucester.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Deny to speak with me? They are sick? they are weary? They have travell'd all the night? Mere fetches- The images of revolt and flying off! Fetch me a better answer.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: My dear lord, You know the fiery quality of the Duke, How unremovable and fix'd he is In his own course.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Vengeance! plague! death! confusion! Fiery? What quality? Why, Gloucester, Gloucester, I'ld speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Well, my good lord, I have inform'd them so.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Inform'd them? Dost thou understand me, man?

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: Ay, my good lord.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: The King would speak with Cornwall; the dear father Would with his daughter speak, commands her service. Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blood! Fiery? the fiery Duke? Tell the hot Duke that- No, but not yet! May be he is not well. Infirmity doth still neglect all office Whereto our health is bound. We are not ourselves When nature, being oppress'd, commands the mind To suffer with the body. I'll forbear; And am fallen out with my more headier will, To take the indispos'd and sickly fit For the sound man.- Death on my state! Wherefore Should be sit here? This act persuades me That this remotion of the Duke and her Is practice only. Give me my servant forth. Go tell the Duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them- Now, presently. Bid them come forth and hear me, Or at their chamber door I'll beat the drum Till it cry sleep to death.

speaker: Gloucester
turn_text: I would have all well betwixt you.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Exit.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: O me, my heart, my rising heart! But down!

speaker: Fool
turn_text: Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put 'em i' th' paste alive. She knapp'd 'em o' th' coxcombs with a stick and cried 'Down, wantons, down!' 'Twas her brother that, in pure kindness to his horse, buttered his hay.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter Cornwall, Regan, Gloucester, Servants.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Good morrow to you both.

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Hail to your Grace!

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Kent here set at liberty.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: I am glad to see your Highness.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Regan, I think you are; I know what reason I have to think so. If thou shouldst not be glad, I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb, Sepulchring an adultress. [To Kent] O, are you free? Some other time for that.- Beloved Regan, Thy sister's naught. O Regan, she hath tied Sharp-tooth'd unkindness, like a vulture, here! [Lays his hand on his heart.] I can scarce speak to thee. Thou'lt not believe With how deprav'd a quality- O Regan!

speaker: Regan
turn_text: I pray you, sir, take patience. I have hope You less know how to value her desert Than she to scant her duty.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Say, how is that?

speaker: Regan
turn_text: I cannot think my sister in the least Would fail her obligation. If, sir, perchance She have restrain'd the riots of your followers, 'Tis on such ground, and to such wholesome end, As clears her from all blame.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: My curses on her!

speaker: Regan
turn_text: O, sir, you are old! Nature in you stands on the very verge Of her confine. You should be rul'd, and led By some discretion that discerns your state Better than you yourself. Therefore I pray you That to our sister you do make return; Say you have wrong'd her, sir.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Ask her forgiveness? Do you but mark how this becomes the house: 'Dear daughter, I confess that I am old. [Kneels.] Age is unnecessary. On my knees I beg That you'll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.'

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Good sir, no more! These are unsightly tricks. Return you to my sister.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: [rises] Never, Regan! She hath abated me of half my train; Look'd black upon me; struck me with her tongue, Most serpent-like, upon the very heart. All the stor'd vengeances of heaven fall On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones, You taking airs, with lameness!

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: Fie, sir, fie!

speaker: Lear
turn_text: You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames Into her scornful eyes! Infect her beauty, You fen-suck'd fogs, drawn by the pow'rful sun, To fall and blast her pride!

speaker: Regan
turn_text: O the blest gods! so will you wish on me When the rash mood is on.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse. Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give Thee o'er to harshness. Her eyes are fierce; but thine Do comfort, and not burn. 'Tis not in thee To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train, To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes, And, in conclusion, to oppose the bolt Against my coming in. Thou better know'st The offices of nature, bond of childhood, Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude. Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot, Wherein I thee endow'd.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Good sir, to th' purpose.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Tucket within.

speaker: Lear
turn_text: Who put my man i' th' stocks?

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: What trumpet's that?

speaker: Regan
turn_text: I know't- my sister's. This approves her letter, That she would soon be here.

speaker: STAGE
turn_text: Enter [Oswald the] Steward.

speaker: Regan
turn_text: Is your lady come?

speaker: Lear
turn_text: This is a slave, whose easy-borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows. Out, varlet, from my sight!

speaker: Cornwall
turn_text: What means your Grace?
